Award.AwardTitle: How motor forces determine the shapes of microtubules in living cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1236616
PI: Ladd

Microtubules have a thermal persistence length of several millimeters but in living cells they are frequently observed to be bent on length scales of just a few microns, indicating the action of large athermal forces. Most experimental force measurements with microtubules have been performed in vitro and are not directly relevant to what happens in vivo. As a result, the microtubule force balance remains unclear. This project aims to develop and validate a biologically relevant model for the forces generated on microtubules by motor proteins. The project offers a new paradigm for investigating force generation in cells, by severing individual microtubules with a laser in living cells, and using numerical models of microtubule mechanics to interpret the measurements.

Most essential mammalian cell functions, including migration and cell division, involve force generation by semi-flexible biopolymers called microtubules. An understanding of how the forces generated by motor proteins affect the shapes and thus the function of microtubules in the cell has applications in a number of fields: cellular transport, cytoskeletal mechanics and cell biology, engineering applications in nanobiotechnology and the understanding of diseases such as cancer. The project promotes a collaborative partnership between multiple investigators, involving experiments, modeling and simulations. The numerical model will form the basis for a long-term development of simulations of the mechanics of the cytoskeleton. In addition, the project contributes to the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students in a diverse, multidisciplinary environment.

This project is co-funded by the Physics of Living Systems in Physics Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most essential mammalian cell functions, including migration and cell division, involve force generation by semi-flexible biopolymers called microtubules. Microtubules have a thermal persistence length of several millimeters but in living cells they are frequently observed to be bent on length scales of just a few microns, indicating the action of large athermal forces. Most experimental force measurements with microtubules have been performed in vitro and are not directly relevant to what happens in vivo. As a result, the microtubule force balance remains unclear. In this projected we have combined experimental observations of microtubule motion, made using confocal microscopy, with numerical simulations of the dynamics of model microtubule-motor systems to elucidate the forces generated by molecular motors on individual microtubule segments.

We first investigated the motion of fluorescently labelled microtubule tips and quantified the random motion of the tips. The effects of the various motors were assessed by inhibition experiments, using standard protocols to essentially switch off various types of motors. Then by observing the differences in the spread of the tip trajectories we could infer which of the motors was playing an important role. The experimental observations showed that dynein makes a significant contribution to the waviness of the tip trajectory whereas other molecular motors, specifically myosin and kinesin I, do not. We then used numerical simulations to try to replicate these results using previously developed models for the motor forces.

Next we investigated the means by which microtubules can develop large bends despite the elastic forces that tend to straighten them. Starting with microtubules that were fluorescently labelled along their length a pattern of dashes was marked by photobleaching. This enabled to see when microtubule segements were actually stationary as opposed to sliding along the exiting contour (reptation). We found that microtubules can be transiently pinned along their length, and that when that happens dynein motors push excess length (like a slack rope) towards the pinned segment. We showed by simulation that this process leads to to the highly curved shapes observed near pinned segments.
